Graphical abstract Ammonia decomposition is a promising method for on-site hydrogen generation for fuel cells. Ruthenium is the most active catalyst for this process, and modulation of its geometric and electronic properties is essential for achieving high catalytic performance. This study developed a facile approach for synthesizing alkali metal-doped Ru/MgO catalysts using a one-pot dry ball milling method with acetates as precursors. Characterization results indicate that K, Rb, and Cs act as effective structural and electronic promoters. Notably, the presence of alkali metals significantly inhibits the aggregation of bulk-like RuO2, leading to the formation of well-dispersed RuO x , which, upon reduction, produces small Ru nanoparticles. The average Ru particle size is about 2–3 nm, aligning with the theoretical optimal size for maximizing B5 sites. XAS and DRIFTS analyses confirm that Ru species are stabilized due to the strong metal-promoter interaction between ruthenium and alkali metals via oxygen bonding. The resulting alkali metal-promoted Ru nanoparticles exhibit superior low-temperature activity for ammonia decomposition. The 2 K-3 %Ru/MgO catalyst achieves a high reaction rate of 11.5 mmol-NH3 gcat −1 min−1 at 400 °C under 30,000 mL gcat −1 h−1, demonstrating one of the highest performances among Ru catalysts. Furthermore, this catalyst maintains high activity at 475 °C for 50 h without significant deactivation. The enhanced catalytic performance is attributed to the structural and electronic promotion effects of alkali metals, which facilitate the formation of B5 site-rich and electron-rich Ru nanoparticles. These findings offer valuable insights into the role of alkali metals and provide helpful guidance for designing efficient alkali metal-promoted ruthenium catalysts for practical applications. Ammonia, as a zero-carbon hydrogen carrier, has garnered considerable attention due to its advantageous properties, including a high hydrogen content (17.8 wt% H2), high volumetric density (108 kg H2/m3 in liquid form), high energy density (3 kWh/kg), ease of liquefaction at 20 °C and 8.6 bar, and an annual global production exceeding one billion tons [1–3]. Additionally, ammonia can be catalytically decomposed into hydrogen and nitrogen without generating carbon oxides (CO x ), and unconverted ammonia can be reduced to below 200 ppb using an appropriate adsorbent, allowing direct utilization of the H2 stream in fuel cells without additional purification. These attributes position ammonia as a viable candidate for on-site H2 generation in fuel cell applications. Ammonia decomposition is a mildly endothermic reaction (2NH3 ↔ N2 + 3H2, ΔH0 = 46.22 kJ mol−1), and a thermodynamic equilibrium conversion exceeding 99 % can be achieved at 400 °C under ambient pressure [4–6]. Therefore, developing a highly efficient low-temperature catalyst is essential for achieving effective ammonia decomposition. Various catalysts, including noble metals, transition metals, carbides, nitrides, and alkali metal amides/imides, have been explored for ammonia decomposition [7–12]. Among these, Ru-based catalysts have attracted considerable interest due to their superior low-temperature activity [13–26]. The catalytic performance of Ru catalysts is highly dependent on their geometric and electronic properties. Ammonia decomposition on Ru catalysts is recognized as a structure-sensitive reaction, with the B5-type site identified as the active site. This site consists of an arrangement of three Ru atoms in one layer and two additional Ru atoms in a sub-surface layer on an Ru (0 0 0 1) surface [27]. The number of B5 sites is influenced by Ru particle size and shape, with an optimal Ru particle size of about 1.8–3 nm for hemispherical particles [20,27–30] and ∼7 nm for elongated particles [20] to maximize B5 site density. Hence, precise control over Ru particle size is required to enhance the number of B5 sites. Furthermore, ammonia decomposition on Ru catalysts is kinetically controlled by the recombinative desorption of nitrogen adatoms [4,31,32], with Ru-N bond activation being significantly influenced by the electronic state of Ru. Electron-rich Ru enhances electron transfer from Ru to the Ru-N antibonding orbital, weakening the Ru-N bond and promoting nitrogen recombination [33]. The fabrication of electron-rich Ru can be achieved through the use of electronically conductive or basic materials as supports, including carbon-based materials (e.g., CNTs) [31,34–39], alkaline earth metal oxides (e.g., MgO [40–48], CaO [49]) perovskites [50,51], barium hexaaluminate [52], [Ca24Al28O64 4+(e−)4] electrides [33], and CaCN2 cyanamide [53]. Another widely adopted strategy involves modifying Ru catalysts with alkali metals [34,35,54–57], which function as electronic promoters by donating electrons to Ru. The electron transfer from supports and/or promoters to Ru has been demonstrated to enhance catalytic performance. Among the various Ru catalysts studied, Ru/MgO has demonstrated high catalytic activity owing to the efficient metal-support interaction and electron-donating ability of basic sites in MgO. Extensive research has been conducted on the synthesis of Ru/MgO catalysts using wet-chemical methods such as precipitation [40,42], deposition–precipitation [42,44,46], and colloid deposition [43,45]. For instance, Ju et al. [44] synthesized a Ru/MgO catalyst through deposition–precipitation via urea hydrolysis. The 3 %Ru/c-MgO catalyst exhibited a Ru particle size of 3.5 nm, achieving 87 % ammonia conversion at 475 °C under a space velocity (SV) of 30,000 mL gcat −1 h−1, which increased to 96 % upon K doping. To enhance Ru atomic utilization, Li et al. [47] developed a sub-nm (1.0 nm) Ru cluster catalyst using a host–guest approach with metal–organic framework MIL-101 as the host material. The 3 %Ru-Cs/MgO-MIL catalyst exhibited nearly complete ammonia conversion at 450 °C (SV = 15,000 mL gcat −1 h−1), with high activity attributed to excellent Ru dispersion and a high concentration of B5 sites. More recently, Fang et al. [41] reported an atomically dispersed Ru catalyst supported on MgO nanosheets with preferentially exposed (1 1 1) facets. The 3 %Ru/MgO(1 1 1) catalyst achieved nearly full ammonia conversion at 450 °C (SV = 30,000 mL gcat −1 h−1), representing a state-of-the-art catalyst for ammonia decomposition. This outstanding activity was attributed to the synergistic effect of efficient hydrogen spillover and nitrogen recombination at closely positioned Ru pairs on polar MgO(1 1 1). Despite these advancements, conventional catalyst preparation methods are often labor-intensive and time-consuming, involving multiple steps such as MgO synthesis, Ru immobilization, alkali metal doping, and repeated drying, calcination, and reduction treatments, along with the extensive use of solvents. Furthermore, alkali metal doping via post-synthesis impregnation does not always lead to improved catalytic performance. From a practical standpoint, the development of a simple and efficient method for controlled Ru catalyst synthesis is essential. In this study, a facile one-pot dry ball milling approach was employed for the preparation of alkali metal-doped Ru/MgO catalysts. Ruthenium acetate, magnesium acetate, and alkali metal acetate were used as precursors and homogeneously mixed via dry ball milling, followed by calcination and reduction treatments. The use of identical acetate precursors ensured uniform mixing of the starting materials. Compared to conventional multistep synthesis, the one-pot dry ball milling method integrates support synthesis, active metal immobilization, and promoter doping into a single step, significantly simplifying the preparation process and reducing synthesis time. A range of alkali metal-doped Ru/MgO catalysts was synthesized by varying the Ru and alkali metal (Li, Na, K, Rb, Cs) contents. To explore the structural and electronic properties of ruthenium, the as-prepared catalysts were characterized using multiple techniques, including X-ray powder diffraction (XRD), temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR) and desorption (CO2-TPD), high-angle annular dark-field scanning transmission electron microscopy (HAADF-STEM) coupled with energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDX), X-ray absorption spectroscopy (XAS), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), and in situ diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier-transform spectroscopy (DRIFTS). The results indicate that K, Rb, and Cs function as structural and electronic promoters, with strong metal-promoter interactions leading to forming B5 site-rich and electron-rich Ru nanoparticles (NPs) with superior catalytic performance. To the best of our knowledge, few reports have investigated the dual promotional role of alkali metals, particularly their significant impact on Ru dispersion. These findings offer valuable insights for the efficient modification of ruthenium catalysts with alkali metals. Given the enormous diversity of metal precursors, the one-pot synthesis strategy can be broadly applied to developing other metal oxide-supported and alkali-promoted noble metal catalysts for wide applications. 2 Experimental 2.1 Preparation of catalysts Alkali metal-doped Ru/MgO catalysts were prepared via one-pot dry ball milling. The acetate precursors including Ru(CH3COO)3·xH2O (Macklin), Mg(CH3COO)2·4H2O (Macklin), CH3COOLi·2H2O (Aladdin), CH3COONa (Aladdin), CH3COOK·xH2O (Macklin), CH3COORb·xH2O (Alfa Aesar), and CH3COOCs·xH2O (Aladdin) were used as received without further treatment. Ball milling was performed on a MITR planetary ball mill in an agate tank (volume 250 cc) containing one hundred ϕ5 mm agate balls and fifty ϕ10 mm agate balls with a ball to powder ratio about 19 (99.3 g balls and 5.2 g samples). Ball milling was run for 2 h at a speed of 800 rpm. After that, the mixture powder was transferred to a crucible and calcined in a muffle furnace under static air at 500 °C for 5 h. The obtained product was pressed into a disk, and then crushed and sieved to grain size of 30–60 mesh. The as-prepared catalysts are described as xAM-y%Ru/MgO, where x refers the molar ratio of alkali metal to Ru (x = 0–4), and y% is the weight percentage of Ru (y% = 1 %, 3 %, 5 %). 2.2 Catalyst characterization The actual Ru content was measured by inductively coupled plasma-optical emission spectroscopy (ICP-OES) on OPTIMA 8000 (PerkinElmer) after the sample was completely dissolved with diluted nitro-hydrochloric acid. Field emission scanning electron microscopy (FE-SEM) was taken on a Hitachi S-4800 microscope operated at 5.0 kV and 7 μA. N2 physisorption measurement was conducted at –196 °C on ASAP 2020 surface analyzer (Micromeritics). The specific surface area was calculated by Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) method, and the pore size distribution was determined via Barrett–Joyner–Halenda (BJH) method. The crystalline structure of the samples was measured by XRD on a PANalytical X’PertPro diffractometer using monochromatized Co Kα radiation (λ = 0.1789 nm) at 40 kV and 40 mA. The reducibility of Ru species in the calcined sample was studied by H2-TPR on a Micrometrics AutoChem 2920 analyzer. Typically, about 100 mg of sample was loaded in a quartz U-tube and then treated in Ar flow at 300 °C for 0.5 h. After cooling to 50 °C, the sample was heated to 800 °C (10 °C min−1) under a 10 vol% H2/Ar flow (30 mL min−1), during which H2 consumption was recorded with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). HAADF-STEM and EDX measurements were performed on a Thermo Fisher Scientific TEM using 300 kV acceleration voltage and 25 mrad convergence angle. An annular darkfield detector at 91 mm camera length was used for signal acquisition, with inner and outer collection angles of 60 and 200 mrad for HAADF imaging, respectively. The Ru particle-size distributions were obtained by accounting more than one-hundred particles, and the average sizes (Sauter mean diameters) were calculated by the equation: d = Σn i d i 3/Σn i d i 2, where n i is the number of particles with a diameter of d i (nm). The Ru dispersion (D) was calculated with the equation: D (%) = 1.29/d × 100 % [15,58]. The number of surface Ru atoms on the reduced catalysts was measured by CO pulse chemisorption on the AutoChem2920 analyzer. Typically, approximately 100 mg of calcined sample was reduced in H2 (30 mL min−1) at 500 °C for 1 h and then purged with He (30 mL min−1) for 0.5 h. After cooling down to 50 °C in He flow, CO chemisorption was done by pulsing a 5 vol% CO/He gas until saturation adsorption, during which the CO uptake was monitored with TCD. The number of surface Ru atoms was calculated by assuming a stoichiometric ratio of CO:Ru = 1:1. XAS analysis at Ru K-edge (E 0 = 22117 eV) was performed at BL14W1 beamline of Shanghai Synchrotron Radiation Facility (SSRF) operated at 3.5 GeV under “topup” mode with a constant current of 220 mA. The calcined sample was reduced with hydrogen at 500 ℃ in a fixed-bed reactor, and the reduced catalyst was used for XAS analysis without any in situ pretreatment. The XAFS data were recorded under fluorescence mode with standard Lytle ion chamber. The absorption edge of Ru foil was used to calibrate the energy. The obtained XAFS data was processed in Athena (version 0.9.26) for background, pre-edge line and post-edge line calibrations. Then Fourier transformed fitting was carried out in Artemis (version 0.9.26). The k 3 weighting, k-range of 3–12 Å−1, and R range of 1–4 Å were used for fitting. The four parameters including coordination number (CN), bond length (R), Debye-Waller factor (σ2), and E0 shift (ΔE0) were fitted without anyone was fixed, constrained, or correlated. Temperature-programmed desorption of CO2 (CO2-TPD) measurements were performed on AutoChem 2920 analyzer. Typically, 100 mg of calcined sample was reduced in 10 %H2/Ar flow (30 mL min−1) at 500 °C for 1 h, and then cooled down to 50 °C in He flow. Subsequently, the reduced catalyst was exposed to CO2 (30 mL min−1) at 50 °C for 1 h, followed by purging with He for 0.5 h. CO2-TPD profiles were recorded with increasing temperature to 550 °C (10 °C min−1) under He flow (30 mL min−1). The signal of CO2 (m/z = 44) was monitored with a mass spectrometer (Hiden Analytical QGA). In situ DRIFTS was recorded on Vertex 80v sample Compartment RT-Dla TGS (Bruker Optics) equipped with a mercury cadmium telluride (MCT) detector cooled by liquid nitrogen. The calcined sample was reduced in the cell with 10 %H2/Ar (30 mL min−1) at 500 °C for 0.5 h and then purged with He at 500 °C for 0.5 h. CO adsorption was done in 5 %CO/He (30 mL min−1) at 50 °C for 0.5 h, followed by purging with He for 0.5 h. All spectra were recorded at the range of 600–4000 cm−1 by accumulating 32 scans with a resolution of 4 cm−1. XPS was conducted on a Thermo Scientific ESCALAB 250 spectrometer using Al Kα radiation (1486.8 eV) as the excitation source. The calcined sample was ex-situ reduced with pure H2 at 500 °C for 0.5 h in a fixed-bed reactor. The reduced sample was transferred to the XPS reaction chamber and treated with 10 %H2/Ar at 500 °C for 0.5 h to eliminate the oxidation of Ru metal by air during sample transferring. Subsequently, the sample was moved to the preparation chamber with high vacuum and to the analysis chamber without exposure to air. All binding energies (BEs) were calibrated with respect to the C 1s peak (284.8 eV) arising from adventitious carbon. Temperature-programmed surface reaction (TPSR) measurement was reperformed on the AutoChem 2920 analyzer. Before measurement, the calcined sample (100 mg) was pre-reduced in H2 (30 mL min−1) at 500 °C for 1 h, and then cooled down to 50 °C in He flow. Subsequently, a 10 %NH3/He flow (30 mL min−1) was introduced, and the temperature was raised from 50 to 600 °C (10 °C min−1). The signals of NH3 (m/z = 17), H2 (m/z = 2), and N2 (m/z = 28) were tracked with a mass spectrometer (Hiden Analytical HPR-20 TMS). 2.3 Catalytic tests Catalytic ammonia decomposition was conducted in a fixed-bed quartz-tube reactor (inner diameter = 6 mm) under atmosphere pressure. Typically, about 50 mg of calcined sample (30–60 mesh) was reduced with hydrogen (30 mL min−1) by raising the temperature from ambient to 500 °C (10 °C min−1) and holding at 500 °C for 0.5 h. After the reduction treatment, the temperature was decreased to 300 °C in N2 flow (30 mL min−1), and then a pure NH3 gas (25 mL min−1) was flowed into the reactor with a space velocity of 30,000 mL gcat −1 h−1, and the temperature was raised up to 550 °C at an interval of 25 °C. The concentration of ammonia in the exit gas was analyzed by a gas chromatograph (GC9790 II) equipped with TCD and a column specially for the analysis of ammonia. The NH3 conversion (X NH3) and H2 formation rate (r H2) were calculated by the following equations, where F(NH3)inlet and F(NH3)outlet were the flow rate of NH3 in the inlet and outlet streams, and M cat. was the catalyst mass, respectively: X(NH3) (%) = (F(NH3)inlet–F(NH3)outlet)/F(NH3)inlet × 100 % r(NH3) (mmol gcat −1 min−1) = F(NH3)inlet × X(NH3)/(22.4 × M cat.) The long-term stability of the catalyst was evaluated at 475 °C for 50 h under 30,000 mL gcat −1 h−1. The kinetics measurement was carried out at 400 °C using 100–150 mesh sample, which was diluted with 100–150 mesh silica to prevent temperature gradients (20 mg 3 %Ru/MgO + 30 mg SiO2; 5 mg 2 K-3 %Ru/MgO + 45 mg SiO2). The partial pressures of ammonia, nitrogen, and hydrogen were varied in the range of 10 ∼ 30 % NH3, 0 ∼ 20 % H2, and 0 ∼ 40 % N2, and He was used as balance gas to keep a total flow rate of 100 mL min−1. In all cases, the ammonia conversion was below 15 %. The reaction rate of ammonia was determined by the power law equation according to the Temkin–Pyzhev mechanism: r = kP NH3 α P N2 β P H2 γ, where k refers the reaction rate constant, and α, β, γ are the reaction order of ammonia, nitrogen, and hydrogen, respectively. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of the Ru catalysts The actual Ru content in the calcined samples was determined using ICP-OES, as summarized in Table 1 . The measured Ru content was slightly lower than the nominal value, which can be attributed to the evaporation of oxidic Ru species during the calcination process [49,59]. A slight increase in Ru content was observed upon doping with K, Rb, and Cs, likely due to the stabilization of RuO x by alkali metals (vide infra). SEM images of the calcined samples (Fig. S1) reveal the presence of numerous grains with a sphere-like morphology and relatively uniform sizes. The N2 adsorption–desorption isotherms and pore-size distributions of the calcined samples (Fig. S2) indicate the presence of a hysteresis loop in the relative pressure range of p/p0 = 0.7–1.0, which corresponds to type H3 hysteresis according to the IUPAC classification. The most probable pore diameter was about 20 nm. As summarized in Table S1, the BET specific surface area of the calcined samples ranged from 24.5 to 37.5 m2 gcat −1, with a pore volume between 0.14 and 0.23 cm3 gcat −1. The XRD patterns of various alkali metal-doped 3 %Ru/MgO calcined samples are presented in Fig. 1 A. In all cases, intense diffraction peaks corresponding to MgO (cubic Fm-3 m) are observed, indicating the formation of highly crystalline MgO. The average crystallite size of MgO, calculated using the Scherrer equation based on the strongest (2 0 0) peak, ranges from 25 to 40 nm (Table S1). For the 3 %Ru/MgO sample, diffraction peaks at 2θ = 32.6°, 40.9°, and 63.9° correspond to the (1 1 0), (1 0 1), and (2 1 1) planes of RuO2 (tetragonal P42/mnm), indicating the presence of aggregated bulk-like RuO2. This suggests a weak metal-support interaction between Ru and MgO. Notably, RuO2 diffraction peaks are partially attenuated upon doping with Li and Na. More significantly, no distinct RuO2 peaks are detected in K-, Rb-, and Cs-doped samples, implying the formation of well-dispersed RuO x . This finding underscores a strong metal-promoter interaction between RuO x and alkali metal species, effectively preventing the aggregation of RuO x . Regardless of the alkali metal used, no diffraction peaks corresponding to alkali metal compounds are detected, suggesting that the alkali metal species remain in a highly dispersed state. H2-TPR analysis was conducted to examine the reducibility of Ru and obtain further insights into its chemical state. As shown in Fig. 1B, multiple reduction peaks are observed in all samples, indicating the existence of various ruthenium oxide species. For 3 %Ru/MgO, the reduction peak at 138 °C corresponds to well-dispersed RuO x , while peaks in the range of 158–186 °C are associated with different sizes of bulk-like RuO2. A minor peak above 200 °C is likely attributed to isolated Ru species strongly interacting with the MgO support [45,60]. Upon doping with Li and Na, the RuO2 reduction peak shifts slightly toward lower temperatures, which may indicate a reduction in RuO2 particle size. In contrast, the K-, Rb-, and Cs-doped samples exhibit a predominant reduction peak around 140 °C, with no distinct peak corresponding to RuO2, suggesting that well-dispersed RuO x is the dominant phase and aggregation of RuO2 is completely inhibited. These findings demonstrate that K, Rb, and Cs effectively facilitate the dispersion and stabilization of RuO x species. The XRD patterns of alkali metal-doped 3 %Ru/MgO catalysts after reduction are displayed in Fig. 1C. In the case of 3 %Ru/MgO, diffraction peaks at 2θ = 44.9°, 49.4°, and 51.6° correspond to the (1 0 0), (0 0 2), and (1 0 1) planes of Ru metal (hexagonal P63/mmc), indicating the reduction of bulk-like RuO2 into large-sized Ru metal. For Li- and Na-doped catalysts, Ru metal diffraction peaks are present with intensities comparable to those of the undoped catalyst. The estimated average crystallite sizes of Ru metal are 17.7, 19.2, and 19.7 nm for the undoped, Li-doped, and Na-doped catalysts, respectively. Given the attenuation of RuO2 diffraction peaks in calcined samples, it is inferred that Ru metal sintering occurs during reduction, indicating that Li and Na do not effectively suppress Ru metal sintering. In contrast, no diffraction peaks corresponding to Ru metal are observed for the K-, Rb-, and Cs-doped catalysts, suggesting a highly dispersed state of Ru. These results indicate that K, Rb, and Cs act as efficient structural promoters, stabilizing Ru metal against sintering and enhancing its dispersion. Similarly, no diffraction peaks corresponding to alkali metal compounds are detected, indicating a highly dispersed state of alkali metal species. To investigate the dispersion and particle size of Ru in the reduced catalysts, aberration-corrected HAADF-STEM analysis was conducted. The representative HAADF-STEM images and the corresponding Ru particle size distributions, obtained from both low- and high-resolution images, are presented in Fig. 2 . The undoped 3 %Ru/MgO catalyst contains some large Ru particles (∼5–30 nm), exhibiting a broad size distribution with an average particle size of 16.2 nm. In the case of Li- and Na-doped catalysts, the Ru particle size distribution and average size remain largely unchanged, indicating that Li and Na exert minimal influence on Ru dispersion. In contrast, the K-, Rb-, and Cs-doped catalysts primarily consist of small Ru NPs (<3 nm), which are uniformly distributed on the support with a narrow size distribution. High-resolution images reveal that these Ru NPs adopt a hemispherical shape, with no evidence of large Ru particle formation. The average Ru particle sizes are estimated to be 2.3 nm for both K- and Rb-doped catalysts and 3.3 nm for the Cs-doped catalyst, about 5–7 times smaller than that of the undoped sample. Notably, these particle sizes are in close agreement with the theoretically optimal Ru particle size for B5 sites (∼1.8–3 nm) [20,27–30], indicating the formation of B5 site-rich Ru NPs. These results demonstrate a remarkable promotional effect of K, Rb, and Cs in enhancing Ru dispersion. The number of surface Ru atoms in the reduced catalysts was determined through CO chemisorption, with the results summarized in Table 1. Similar values were observed for the undoped and Li-, Na-doped catalysts, whereas a significant increase was recorded for the K-, Rb-, and Cs-doped catalysts. The highest value, 71.8 μmol-Ru gcat −1, was obtained for the K-doped catalyst, followed by the Rb- and Cs-doped counterparts. Table 1 also presents Ru dispersion and particle size, as calculated from CO chemisorption, XRD, and STEM analyses. For the undoped and Li-, Na-doped catalysts, Ru dispersion values derived from XRD and STEM were lower than those obtained from CO chemisorption, which may be attributed to the underestimation of small Ru NPs by XRD and STEM. In contrast, for the K-, Rb-, and Cs-doped catalysts, the dispersion values determined by STEM exceeded those obtained from CO chemisorption. A plausible explanation for this discrepancy is the partial coverage of the Ru nanoparticle surfaces by alkali metal species [31,55,61], which obstructs CO adsorption on the Ru surface. This interpretation is further supported by evidence of Ru–KO x interface formation on the K-doped catalyst, as indicated by CO2-TPD (vide infra). Overall, the K-doped catalyst exhibited high Ru dispersion and a large number of surface Ru sites, indicating that K functions as an effective structural promoter. To gain deeper insights into the structural and electronic properties of ruthenium and its interaction with alkali metal species and the MgO support, further characterization was conducted using 2 K-3 %Ru/MgO as a representative sample. Fig. 3 displays aberration-corrected HAADF-STEM images and EDX elemental mappings of the calcined and reduced 2 K-3 %Ru/MgO. In the calcined sample, both ruthenium and potassium are well-dispersed and evenly distributed across the MgO support. High-resolution images (Fig. S3) indicate that RuO x species primarily exist as small NPs (<2 nm) with a hemispherical morphology. It is inferred that K species are positioned between RuO x NPs, surrounding them. After reduction, ruthenium and potassium remain well-dispersed, demonstrating good thermal stability. This suggests that the surrounding K species function as both separators and stabilizers, preventing Ru sintering into large particles. To elucidate the interaction between Ru and K species, XAS analysis was conducted to investigate the coordination environment and local structure of ruthenium. Fig. 4 A presents the Ru K-edge XANES spectra of the calcined and reduced 2 K-3 %Ru/MgO, along with those of 3 %Ru/MgO and Ru foil as references. The Ru K-edge XANES spectra of the calcined samples closely resemble that of the RuO2 reference [15,45,47]; however, the adsorption edge of 2 K-3 %Ru/MgO exhibits a slight shift toward lower energy, indicating a reduced oxidation state of well-dispersed RuO x species. This shift may be attributed to electron transfer from electron-rich O2− in KO x to electron-deficient Ru4+ in RuO x , suggesting the formation of a Ru-O-K interaction between RuO x and KO x . Upon reduction, the Ru K-edge shifts further toward lower energy, approaching that of Ru foil, confirming that the majority of Ru species are reduced to metallic Ru. Compared to 3 %Ru/MgO, 2 K-3 %Ru/MgO exhibits a higher edge intensity along with a slight shift to higher energy, indicating the presence of partially oxidized Ru δ + species (0 < δ < 4). Previous studies on alkali-promoted noble metal catalysts, such as Na-Ru1/Al2O3 [62], Na-Pt/TiO2 [63], and K-Pt@silicalite-1 [64], have reported that alkali ions interact with active metal sites through surrounding oxygen atoms (e.g., Pt-O-Na, Pt-O-K), which helps stabilize metal sites in an oxidic state. Therefore, the partially oxidized Ru δ + species in this system is likely due to ruthenium atoms situated at the interface between Ru NPs and KO x , where strong Ru-O-K interactions are present. Although the partial oxidation of Ru metal by air during sample transfer to the XAS chamber cannot be fully excluded, it is reasonable to infer that K doping promotes the formation of Ru δ + species due to the presence of adjacent KO x . The Fourier-transformed k 3-weighted Ru K-edge EXAFS spectra are displayed in Fig. 4B, and the corresponding fitting results are summarized in Table 2 . The calcined samples exhibit two peaks at ∼1.97 Å and ∼3.14 Å (phase-shift corrected), corresponding to the Ru-O and Ru-Ru bonds of RuO2, respectively. The Ru-O CN for 3 %Ru/MgO is about 5.8, comparable to that of RuO2 reference material [47], whereas for 2 K-3 %Ru/MgO, it decreases to 5.0, indicating the under-coordination of RuO x . A peak at 2.68 Å is observed in the reduced catalysts, which corresponds to the Ru-Ru bond of metallic Ru. The Ru-Ru CN decreases from 7.3 in 3 %Ru/MgO to 4.1 in 2 K-3 %Ru/MgO, which aligns with the formation of small Ru NPs. Notably, the Ru-O bond persists in the reduced 2 K-3 %Ru/MgO, with a Ru-O distance of 2.01 Å, slightly longer than that of RuO2 (1.97 Å). This observation further confirms the presence of Ru-O-K interactions between Ru NPs and KO x . It is inferred that the metal-promoter interaction between Ru and KO x is significantly stronger than the metal-support interaction between Ru and MgO, and the strong Ru-O-K interaction plays a crucial role in stabilizing well-dispersed RuO x species and the resulting Ru NPs during calcination and reduction treatments. To further investigate the interface between Ru NPs and KO x species, CO2-TPD was performed (Fig. 5 A). A broad peak was observed for 3 %Ru/MgO at the temperature range of 75 ∼ 350 °C, which could be assigned to CO2 adsorbed on basic sites of MgO [44,65]. By comparison, the CO2 desorption peak is shifted toward higher temperature of 105 ∼ 450 °C for 2 K-3 %Ru/MgO, suggesting enhanced surface basicity. Notably, an additional intense peak at ∼255 °C appears. This is similar to that observed on Ba-Ru/MgO and Cs-Ru/MgO catalysts [65] and can be assigned to CO2 adsorbed on the Ru–KO x interfaces. The presence of such peak indicates the formation of intimate Ru–KO x interfaces. The chemical state of ruthenium was further examined using in situ DRIFTS with CO as a probe molecule. The corresponding spectra are presented in Fig. 5B. For 3 %Ru/MgO, two prominent bands are detected at 2047 cm−1 and 1992 cm−1, which correspond to CO linearly and bridge-adsorbed on Ru particles, respectively [66–70]. In contrast, for 2 K-3 %Ru/MgO, along with the linear- and bridged-CO bands at 2045 cm−1 and 1963 cm−1, an additional intense band appears at 2164 cm−1. This band is attributed to polycarbonyl species [66,70] adsorbed at interface Ru δ + sites that exhibit strong Ru-O-K interactions. The high intensity of this band suggests a significant presence of Ru δ + sites, further indicating substantial Ru-O-K interactions between Ru NPs and KO x . Additionally, the bridged CO band is shifted to a lower wavenumber, which is associated with an increase in electron density in Ru NPs. To investigate the electronic interaction between Ru and K species, XPS analysis was conducted to examine the electronic state of the reduced catalysts. Fig. 6 presents the Ru 3p and K 2p spectra for the reduced 3 %Ru/MgO and 2 K-3 %Ru/MgO catalysts. In the case of 3 %Ru/MgO, the metallic Ru 3p3/2 and 3p1/2 doublet peaks appear at binding energies (BEs) of 483.8 eV and 462.0 eV, respectively [41]. By contrast, the 2 K-3 %Ru/MgO catalyst exhibits peaks shifted to lower BEs at 482.8 eV and 460.6 eV, suggesting an electron-enriched state of Ru NPs. Meanwhile, a shoulder peak at 463.4 eV is observed, which can be attributed to interface Ruδ+ with strong Ru-O-K interactions. Additionally, the K 2p3/2 peak for 2 K-3 %Ru/MgO is located at 293.0 eV, which is higher than the 292.0 eV reported for potassium oxide [71]. These BE shifts provide clear evidence of an electronic interaction between Ru NPs and KO x , indicating electron transfer from KO x to Ru NPs. This confirms that K acts as an electron donor, modifying the electronic state of Ru and facilitating the formation of electron-rich Ru NPs. A similar trend is observed for the Rb- and Cs-doped 3 %Ru/MgO catalysts, as shown in Fig. S4 and Fig. S5. The XRD and H2-TPR characterization results for K-doped Ru/MgO catalysts with varying K/Ru molar ratios and Ru contents are presented in Fig. S6 and Fig. S7. Regardless of the K/Ru molar ratio, the introduction of K into 3 %Ru/MgO effectively prevents the aggregation of bulk-like RuO2, facilitating the formation of well-dispersed RuO x , which upon reduction yields small Ru NPs. This promotional effect is also observed when the Ru content is increased to 5 %, further confirming the role of K in improving Ru dispersion. These findings reaffirm that K serves as an effective structural promoter, contributing to the enhanced dispersion of Ru species. The characterization results presented above demonstrate that K, Rb, and Cs act as both effective structural and electronic promoters. This finding contrasts with most previous studies, where alkali metals were reported to act solely as electronic promoters. The origin of this discrepancy lies in the catalyst preparation method. Conventionally, alkali metals were introduced to pre-synthesized Ru catalysts via impregnation, where Ru particles were already formed and retained their size after doping. As a result, the alkali metals had no influence on Ru dispersion and acted exclusively as electronic promoters. In contrast, the one-pot dry ball milling approach involves the homogeneous mixing of ruthenium, alkali metal, and magnesium precursors. Upon calcination, the alkali metal species surrounding the Ru species inhibit the aggregation of bulk-like RuO2, leading to the formation of well-dispersed RuO x . Moreover, these surrounding alkali metal species stabilize the Ru NPs against sintering during the subsequent reduction process. The uniform mixing of ruthenium and alkali metal precursors, combined with the resulting strong metal–promoter interactions, underpins the structural promotion effect of alkali metals on Ru dispersion. 3.2 Catalytic performance for ammonia decomposition The catalytic activity of Ru catalysts for ammonia decomposition was assessed at a space velocity of 30,000 mL gcat −1 h−1 using non-diluted ammonia as the feed gas. Fig. 7 A illustrates the ammonia conversion over alkali metal-doped 3 %Ru/MgO catalysts within the temperature range of 300–550 °C. The 3 %Ru/MgO catalyst exhibits relatively low activity, achieving only 88 % ammonia conversion at 550 °C. The incorporation of alkali metals enhances catalytic activity, with the extent of improvement depending on the specific alkali metal. Notably, doping with K, Rb, and Cs significantly enhances activity, resulting in >95 % ammonia conversion at 500 °C. Fig. 7B compares the reaction rates at 400 °C among the Ru catalysts. The K-, Rb-, and Cs-doped catalysts exhibit high reaction rates of 11.5, 10.8, and 9.7 mmol-NH3 gcat −1 min−1, representing 3.0, 2.8, and 2.6 times the rate observed for the undoped catalyst, respectively. The overall promoting effect of alkali metals follows the order K > Rb > Cs > Na > Li. Fig. 7C displays the turnover frequencies (TOF) at 400 °C for these Ru catalysts, calculated based on the number of surface Ru atoms determined by CO chemisorption. The TOF value increases from 1.6 s−1 to 2.0, 2.5, 2.7, 3.0, and 3.3 s−1 upon doping with Li, Na, K, Rb, and Cs, respectively, indicating an enhancement in intrinsic activity. This suggests that the substantial improvement in ammonia conversion observed with K-, Rb-, and Cs-doping is attributed not only to increased Ru dispersion but also to an increase in the intrinsic activity of Ru NPs. Fig. 7D presents the Arrhenius plots along with the apparent activation energy (E a), which was calculated from the slope of the plots. The introduction of alkali metals results in a reduction of E a, decreasing from 72.8 kJ mol−1 for 3 %Ru/MgO to 63.0–64.2 kJ mol−1 with Na, K, and Rb doping, and further to 56.7 kJ mol−1 with Cs doping. The trend in E a values generally follows the order of alkali metal electronegativity, where lower electronegativity corresponds to a lower E a. This indicates that the electronic interaction between ruthenium and alkali metal contributes to catalytic enhancement. It is well established that alkali metals act as electron donors, transferring electrons to Ru and thereby facilitating the recombinative desorption of nitrogen adatoms [36,44,46]. Ammonia decomposition typically proceeds through the subsequent cleavage of N–H bonds followed by the recombinative desorption of N and H, with N recombination recognized as the rate-determining step [4,31,41,44,72]. It has been established that Ru particles approximately 1.8–3 nm in size, with a maximal concentration of B5 sites, display high intrinsic catalytic activity, and that electron enrichment of Ru particles facilitates nitrogen recombination by lowering the activation barrier, thereby enhancing the reaction rate. Based on these insights, the improved catalytic performance of alkali metal-doped Ru/MgO catalysts can be attributed to both the structural and electronic promotional effects exerted by the alkali metals. Since Li and Na have minimal influence on Ru dispersion, the observed TOF increase is primarily due to their weak to moderate electronic promotion effects. In contrast, K-, Rb-, and Cs-doping enhances Ru dispersion and provide strong electron donation. This dual promotional effect leads to the formation of B5 site-rich, electron-enriched Ru NPs, which collectively contribute to high TOF. Among the alkali metals, Cs possesses lower electronegativity and a stronger electron-donating capacity, providing a greater electronic promotional effect that results in a higher TOF relative to its counterparts. Furthermore, the decrease of E a indicates that doping alkali metals lowers the activation barrier for the rate-determining N recombination step. This behavior can be attributed to the electronic promotion effect of alkali metals, with the variations in activation energies among alkali metal-doped catalysts arising from the differing electron-donating capacities of the alkali metals. Among these, K demonstrates a stronger structural promotion effect, increasing the number of accessible surface Ru sites and thereby enhancing the overall reaction rate. Due to its superior ability to promote Ru dispersion, K outperforms Cs in terms of overall catalytic activity. This observation contrasts with earlier studies [43,73], where Cs was reported as a more effective promoter than K when alkali metals were introduced to pre-synthesized Ru catalysts via impregnation. In such systems, alkali metals functioned solely as electronic promoters, and Cs exhibited a stronger promotional effect than K due to its higher electron-donating capability. These findings underscore that the overall promotional effect of alkali metals is closely tied to their functional role, which is strongly influenced by the catalyst preparation method. The activities of the xK-3 %Ru/MgO catalysts with varying K/Ru molar ratios are shown in Fig. S8. The overall catalytic activity increases as the K content increases and stabilizes at a K/Ru molar ratio of 2–4, suggesting that an optimal K/Ru molar ratio is around 2. Fig. S9 presents the activities of the 2 K-y%Ru/MgO catalysts with different Ru loadings. As anticipated, the overall activity improves as the Ru content increases from 1 % to 5 %, with K doping leading to a significant enhancement in activity and a noticeable reduction in E a. The 2 K-5 %Ru/MgO catalyst exhibits slightly higher activity than 2 K-3 %Ru/MgO. Regardless of the K/Ru molar ratio or Ru content, all K-doped catalysts display similar E a values, ranging from 59.5 to 66.7 kJ mol−1. A comparison of the catalytic activities of representative Ru catalysts for ammonia decomposition at 400 °C is presented in Fig. S10. Although the activity of the present 2 K-3 %Ru/MgO catalyst is lower than that of atomically dispersed 3 %Ru/MgO(1 1 1) [41], it is comparable to 0.5 K–5 %Ru/MgO-DP [46] and exhibits superior performance compared to other Ru/MgO-based catalysts. Additionally, its performance is similar to that of 1 K-4.8 %Ru/CNT [34], 1Cs-2 %Ru/CeO2{1 0 0} [18], and 1 %Ru/CeO2 [15], while surpassing that of other oxide-supported Ru catalysts. These findings indicate that 2 K-3 %Ru/MgO ranks among the most efficient Ru catalysts. Fig. S11 compares the reaction rates of undoped and alkali metal-doped Ru catalysts prepared using different doping methods. In most cases, one-pot ball milling demonstrates higher doping efficiency than conventional post-synthesis impregnation. The activity enhancement observed in the present 2 K-3 %Ru/MgO catalyst is about threefold, whereas it is only 1.9-, 1.4-, and 1.1-fold for 0.5 K-5 %Ru/MgO [46], 2 K-2.8 %Ru/MgO [43], and 0.5 K-3 %Ru/c-MgO [44], respectively. The K doping efficiency also exceeds those observed for 2 K-5 %Ru/MCM-41 (1.6-fold) [74], 0.5 K-4.8 %Ru/La2O3 (1.5-fold) [57], and 2.1 K-5 %Ru/MgAl-LDO (1.1-fold) [75]. Similarly, the 2Cs-3 %Ru/MgO catalyst demonstrates a higher doping efficiency (2.6-fold) compared to 2Cs-3.1 %Ru/MgO-MIL (2.0-fold) [47], 2Cs-5 %Ru/MgO (1.8-fold) [53], 2Cs-2.8 %Ru/MgO (1.4-fold) [43], 4 %Cs-7 %Ru/graphitized CNT (1.4-fold) [31], and 1Cs-2 %Ru/CeO2{1 0 0} (1.2-fold) [18]. The high doping efficiency is attributed to the exceptional promotional effects of K and Cs on Ru dispersion, which arise from the strong metal-promoter interaction. These results highlight the crucial role of the doping method in optimizing alkali metal promotion for catalytic activity. The long-term catalytic stability of 3 %Ru/MgO and 2 K-3 %Ru/MgO catalysts was evaluated at 475 °C for 50 h. As illustrated in Figs. 8, 3 %Ru/MgO exhibits a noticeable decline in activity over time, with ammonia conversion decreasing from an initial 52 % to 38 % after 50 h of reaction. In contrast, 2 K-3 %Ru/MgO demonstrates significantly enhanced stability. The ammonia conversion gradually decreases from 93 % to 90 % over the first 30 h and remains stable thereafter, indicating relatively good durability. The XRD pattern of the used 2 K-3 %Ru/MgO catalyst reveals a weak peak corresponding to Ru metal's (1 0 1) reflection (Fig. S12A), with no detectable peaks associated with K compounds. Aberration-corrected HAADF-STEM images and EDX mapping (Fig. S12B-D) confirm that most Ru NPs and K species remain well-dispersed without noticeable aggregation. The particle-size distribution indicates that Ru NPs smaller than 3 nm remain predominant. The average Ru NP size is determined to be about 2.3 nm, nearly identical to that observed in the reduced catalyst, suggesting that K-promoted Ru NPs exhibit high stability under reaction conditions. 3.3 NH3-TPSR and kinetic study To further investigate the impact of alkali metal doping on catalytic behavior, NH3-TPSR-MS analysis was performed on 3 %Ru/MgO and 2 K-3 %Ru/MgO to gain insights into ammonia activation. The results are presented in Fig. 9 . The signals of H2 and N2 increase concurrently with the decreasing NH3 signal, confirming the occurrence of ammonia decomposition. For 3 %Ru/MgO, NH3 decomposition begins at about 220 °C and is nearly complete at around 500 °C. In contrast, for 2 K-3 %Ru/MgO, ammonia decomposition initiates at about 160 °C and reaches near-complete conversion at around 400 °C. The lower onset decomposition temperature corresponds to a reduction in reaction activation energy, indicating that the K-promoted Ru NPs in 2 K-3 %Ru/MgO exhibit an enhanced ability for ammonia activation. To further examine the kinetic behavior and hydrogen poisoning effect, reaction orders with respect to ammonia, nitrogen, and hydrogen were determined for 3 %Ru/MgO and 2 K-3 %Ru/MgO. The ammonia decomposition reaction involves basic steps such as adsorption of NH3, cleavage of N–H bonds, and recombinative desorption of N and H adatoms to form N2 and H2. In this case, N recombination is the rate-determining step [4,31,41,44,72]. However, under reaction conditions, hydrogen poisoning commonly occurs on Ru catalysts due to the strong adsorption of hydrogen adatoms on Ru active sites, which obstructs the activation and chemisorption of ammonia and nitrogen species [41]. Fig. 10 A–C presents the ammonia decomposition rate at 400 °C as a function of ammonia, nitrogen, and hydrogen partial pressure, respectively. The ammonia reaction order (α) is small and positive, indicating that nitrogen species strongly adsorb onto the Ru surface, thereby slowing the nitrogen desorption step, consistent with previous studies [41]. The nitrogen reaction order (β) is close to zero, suggesting that the reaction rate is independent of nitrogen partial pressure. The hydrogen reaction order (γ) for 3 %Ru/MgO is negative, reaching –1.33, signifying strong adsorption of hydrogen species on Ru, which hinders ammonia decomposition. In contrast, the hydrogen order for 2 K-3 %Ru/MgO is –0.43, about one-third of that for 3 %Ru/MgO, suggesting weaker hydrogen adsorption on Ru. This implies that hydrogen adatoms are more readily removed from Ru active sites. Previous studies have reported that introducing alkali metals onto Ru surfaces reduces hydrogen adsorption energy and the sticking coefficient [76]. This effect is attributed to electron donation from alkali metal to Ru, which weakens the Ru-H bond strength, thereby suppressing hydrogen adsorption. In summary, the presence of potassium not only enhances Ru dispersion, generating more B5 active sites but also inhibits hydrogen adsorption on Ru, both of which contribute to increasing the availability of Ru sites for ammonia adsorption and activation, thereby promoting ammonia decomposition. Alkali metals (AMs) and alkaline earth metals (AEMs) are well established as effective promoters for Ru catalysts in both ammonia decomposition and synthesis. In conventionally impregnated AM–Ru catalysts, AMs primarily function as electronic promoters, donating electrons to Ru and thereby generating electron-rich Ru sites. Recently, Baik et al. [65] highlighted the crucial role of the BaO–Ru interface in producing electron-enriched Ru under H2 atmospheres. Specifically, chemisorbed H atoms on Ru dissociate into H+/e− pairs at the BaO–Ru interface, where BaO captures H+ while leaving e− on Ru. The separate storage of H+/e− pairs at the BaO–Ru interface induces electron enrichment of Ru, which facilitates N2 activation via improved π-backdonation and concurrently mitigates hydrogen poisoning during NH3 synthesis. More recently, Baik et al. [77] demonstrate that separate Ru and BaO domains on conductive carbon supports can respectively store e− and H+, where H+ migrates over the carbon surface to neutralize BaO, while e− accumulates in conductive Ru/carbon. It is hypothesized that the accumulation of H+/e− pairs at Ru and basic promoter may also play a role in ammonia decomposition, given the fundamentally similar mechanistic frameworks governing both ammonia synthesis and decomposition reactions. In this study, our findings demonstrate that AMs such as K, Rb and Cs act not only as electronic promoters but also as structural promoters that significantly enhance Ru dispersion. The strong metal–promoter interactions between Ru and AM species facilitate the formation of B5 site-rich and electron-rich Ru nanoparticles, along with the development of intimate Ru–AM interfaces. This dual promotional effect imparts the AM–Ru catalysts with markedly superior activity for ammonia decomposition. Overall, the promotional role of AMs is highly dependent on the catalyst preparation method, and precise control over the structural and electronic characteristics of both the Ru phase and the Ru–AM interface is essential for the rational design of highly active catalysts for ammonia decomposition. 4 Conclusions Well-dispersed and highly active K-, Rb-, and Cs-doped Ru/MgO catalysts were successfully synthesized using a one-pot dry ball milling approach. The incorporation of K, Rb, and Cs not only enhances Ru dispersion but also modifies its electronic state. Notably, these alkali metals exhibit a remarkable promotional effect on Ru dispersion. The strong metal-promoter interaction between ruthenium and alkali metal species effectively prevents the aggregation of bulk-like RuO2 and inhibits Ru metal sintering during calcination-reduction treatments, resulting in the formation of small Ru NPs (<3 nm). Doping with K, Rb, and Cs leads to a substantial enhancement in overall catalytic activity and turnover frequency and a reduction in activation energy. A high doping efficiency is achieved with a threefold increase in overall activity at 400 °C for 2 K-3 %Ru/MgO. This catalyst demonstrates superior low-temperature activity compared to most Ru/MgO-based catalysts reported, positioning it among the most effective Ru catalysts. The enhanced catalytic performance is attributed to the structural and electronic promoting effects of alkali metals, which contribute to the formation of B5 site-rich and electron-rich Ru NPs. These findings highlight the role of K, Rb, and Cs as efficient promoters in tuning the geometric, electronic, and catalytic properties of Ru metal sites. The one-pot synthesis strategy and dual promotional effect of alkali metals provide valuable insights for the efficient modification of Ru catalysts with alkali metal species, which will help in developing a practical and active Ru catalyst for ammonia decomposition. coredata.dc:description: Ammonia decomposition is a promising method for on-site hydrogen generation for fuel cells. Ruthenium is the most active catalyst for this process, and modulation of its geometric and electronic properties is essential for achieving high catalytic performance. This study developed a facile approach for synthesizing alkali metal-doped Ru/MgO catalysts using a one-pot dry ball milling method with acetates as precursors. Characterization results indicate that K, Rb, and Cs act as effective structural and electronic promoters. Notably, the presence of alkali metals significantly inhibits the aggregation of bulk-like RuO2, leading to the formation of well-dispersed RuO x , which, upon reduction, produces small Ru nanoparticles. The average Ru particle size is about 2–3 nm, aligning with the theoretical optimal size for maximizing B5 sites. XAS and DRIFTS analyses confirm that Ru species are stabilized due to the strong metal-promoter interaction between ruthenium and alkali metals via oxygen bonding. The resulting alkali metal-promoted Ru nanoparticles exhibit superior low-temperature activity for ammonia decomposition. The 2 K-3 %Ru/MgO catalyst achieves a high reaction rate of 11.5 mmol-NH3 gcat −1 min−1 at 400 °C under 30,000 mL gcat −1 h−1, demonstrating one of the highest performances among Ru catalysts. Furthermore, this catalyst maintains high activity at 475 °C for 50 h without significant deactivation. The enhanced catalytic performance is attributed to the structural and electronic promotion effects of alkali metals, which facilitate the formation of B5 site-rich and electron-rich Ru nanoparticles. These findings offer valuable insights into the role of alkali metals and provide helpful guidance for designing efficient alkali metal-promoted ruthenium catalysts for practical applications.
